title: councils track trace plans government system
story: Three further councils in West Yorkshire plan to create their own contact tracing process in a bid to help curb the spread of infection locally. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Daily Mirror reports that many councils are increasingly concerned that the governments system is failing to identy the volume of contacts needed to prevent regional outbreaks. Track-and-trace, launched in May, is essential to keep the virus at bay as Downing Street looks to avoid ato a national lockdown and prioritise containing local clusters of infections.Contact tracing works by stopping the spread of coronavirus through a community, with authorities hoping that by isolating an infected person you can stop the chain of transmission.Three councils in West Yorkshire - Calderdale, Kirklees and Bradford- are now planning to implement their own system after claiming that the national system isnt up to scratch.Calderdale council, which has the sixth highest infection rate in England, told the Mirror they hope their system will be up and running very soon. Bradford council, meanwhile, said that bosses are in talks with Downing Street while Kirklees is in the very early stages. Manchester mayor Andy Burnham, whose city has seen an alarming rise in infections, also labelled the governments system as not fit for purpose. It comes as Blackburn With Darwen council began developing its own system this week.Under the new rules, local contact tracers will visit people in personthey get cant through to residents by email, text or phone after two days.Director of Public Health at Blackburn with Darwen Council, Professor Dominic Harrison said the national system is not tracing enough cases and contacts fast enough.  Last week, almost , close contacts were missed by contact traces - or  per cent of people - compared with  per cent the week before that.Other areas with spikes in cases such as Leicester and Liverpool launched heavy local action to carry out door-to-door contact tracing to find anyone who might be infectious.The World Health Organisation has thrown its support behind local track and trace systems, with special envoy Dr David Nabarro they were absolutely the right idea.The national system is run by NHS Test and Trace, a £ billion agency that consists of a mixture of Public Health England contact tracers, , health professionals and , call centre workers. It comes as a concerning spike in coronavirus cases has left Downing Street mulling new restrictions for Brits in hard-hit areas.The PM pushed back planned openings of businesses due to open on August  by another two weeks because of warnings of a second spike.And more areas including Manchester were put into a local lockdown last week after a rise in cases.The area declared a major incident days after going into a local lockdown and the mayor called for ato shielding.Infection rates for the week to Thursday - when the new measures were introduced - show cases per , people still rising in every part of the conurbation.Those in Manchester and Tameside have more than doubled in seven days, while Oldhams infections remain the highest and the fastest-growing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weather forecast uk heatwave national emergency
story: The weather this weekend is set to be so scorching that the Met Office has issued an amber health alert for the south east and told people to look out for the vulnerable, elderly and babies.The level three warning is just one step below a national emergency red alert. It is triggered when high temperatures could have a signicant effect on healthreached for two consecutive days and the intervening night.It means there is a strong chance of heatwave conditions between midday on Thursday and am on Sunday. The Met Office warns that increasingly hot conditions are likely across southeastern parts of England from Friday as warm air spreads north from France. Brits are advised to stay cool, drink plenty of water and keep an eye on high-risk groups.The extreme heat warning was issued as today is set to be another sizzler with temperatures reaching C in the south east. It will still be hot where, in the mid to high twenties in most areas.The mercury is set to climb even higher on Friday with temperatures hitting C and many areas seeing thermometers break the C mark.Parts of the country will be hotter than top holiday destinations in the Caribbean, including The Bahamas, Jamaica and Barbados.Temperatures in London and the south east on Friday could even surpass the .C recorded in Heathrow on July  - the hottest day of the year so far, and the UKs third warmest ever.The highest temperatures will be across East Anglia and the south east where it could reach C.The Midlands and parts of Yorkshire will also see temperatures above C. title: melbourne mum pinned cops lockdown rules
story: The unnamed mum, from Melbourne in Australia can be seen struggling against the three officers as her daughter shouts: Shes in pain.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMelbourne, in the state of Victoria is under strict new lockdown rules - including a curfew, after premier Daniel Andrews declared a state of disaster following a spike in Covid- cases.In the footage - filmed before the state entered stage  of its lockdown emergency - a policewoman can be heard telling the daughter: Youre in contravention of the Covid restrictions.The daughter and cop have a heated back-and-forth as the officer attempts to ID the daughter, who claims she was just walking.At one point, the cop accuses her of being a smarta**, adding: You need to take this seriously.“You won’t be arrestedI can confirm your ID.”A spokesperson for the Melbourne force said in a statement: The two females were requested to state their names and address, and produce identication as they were in breach of the chief health officer’s directions.“After numerous attempts from police to have the females provide their details which was refused, they were both arrested.“One of the females resisted arrest, and had to be taken to ground during the incident.A friend of the two women uploaded the footage to Facebook, alongside a snap of a large black bruise on the mums arm.She claimed they had been standing in public “with a poster about Russian politics” when cops approached.Both women were fined ,for breaching the chief health officer’s directions and were released pending enquiries on further charges, cops said.The new lockdown measures in Victoria give cops more powers and include a night-time curfew across Melbourne from pm to am.Pictures show the usually buzzing Australian city eerily quiet with deserted streets and businesses. The curfew will be in place for six weeks, barring the citys nearly five million people from leaving their houses except for work or to receive or give care.Locals will only be allowed to shop and exercise within three miles of their homes, with exercise limited to a single hour.Announcing the measures Sunday, Andrews said: “If we don’t make these changes, were not going to get through this.“We need to do more. That is what these decisions are about.”Treasurer Josh Frydenberg told Nine News: “This is devastating… nobody wanted it to get to this.“There is only one way out and that is to stem the tide of new cases.“This is a big kick in the guts to thousands of small businesses right across the state.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus infections decline after lockdown eased
story: Research shows that infections declined in late June and early July, with infection rates halving every eight to nine days during this time frame - before falling to under eight positive cases per , people.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe findings coming after it was also revealed that thousands of coronavirus deaths are set to be wiped off official records.Scientists raised the alarm after discovering anyone who tests positive and later dies is currently included in the Public Health England numbers - eventhey are hit by a bus months later.It means no-one can ever recover from the virus and all of England’s , confirmed cases would eventually be added to the toll.Health Secretary Matt Hancock will now step in and bring the figures in line with Scotland and Northern Ireland, who only count a death as Covid-relatedit occurs  days after a person tests positive.Experts from Imperial College London and Ipsos MORI used data from , volunteers across England who were being tested for Covid between June  and July .This helped them determine the spread of the virus through the country.From June  non-essential shops were able to reopen and the public were permitted to have further interactions with people outside of their households.This is while at the beginning of July more businesses were able to reopen such as pubs and bars.The data shows that a further relaxation of restrictions did not have an impact on case numbers.The first report was released last month and when compared with this months results the experts found that there were no signicant dferences between the rates of infection for key workers and non-key workers.It also stated that in May the infection rate was also halving every eight to nine days.Professor Paul Elliott, director of the programme at Imperial College London said the research has helped to build a “more informed picture” of how the virus is spreading across the country.He added: “This surveillance programme is showing us the prevalence of infection between dferent demographics, age groups and ethnicities as well as giving us insight into how easing lockdown restrictions are affecting the infection rate.”  Looking specically at how the virus has impacted certain ethnicities and the report found that black, Asian and other ethnic minoritieswere still more likely to test positive than those of white ethnicity.Mr Hancock said the drop in infection rates demonstrates the effectiveness of the countrys infection control measures in limiting the spread of the virus in care homes and hospitals as well as the wider community.He said: This research highlights how, thanks to everyones efforts and sacrice, alongside targeted measures to counter the spread of this virus in health and care settings, we were able to keep rates of infection low as some restrictions were lted.However, we must not be complacent. I urge everyone to get a testyou have symptoms, self-isolate and provide your contacts to NHS Test and Trace so we can continue to keep the virus at bay and get back to normal.Among other signicant findings from the report was the average number of people infected with Covid- falling from , in May to , in June July and no signicant dferences being detected in the rates of infection by age.It also found that there was no signicant dference between male and female infection rates.Looking at where the virus has spread most and the researchers found that case numbers were the highest in London - but lowest in the South West.Key symptoms of the coronavirus include a new persistent cough, high temperature and a loss of taste or smell.The researchers found that  per cent of people testing positive reported no symptoms on the day of the test or on the previous week.The experts highlighted that these people may have developed symptoms later on and that the study does not show how infectious a person was when tested.Another study, focusing on the presence of Covid- antibodies throughout the community, is currently underway.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: test trace not working
story: Contact tracers are missing potentially infectious people because they are calling them from an unrecognisable  number people associate with annoying cold callers. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe LGA has called for a boots on the ground approach in local areas to reach people who may feel they are being pestered by cold callers or debt collectors. A spokesman for the Local Government Association, which represents  councils in England told The : “Many people do not answer the phone to any unrecognised numbers. All of us at one time have been pestered by cold callers. For some hard-to-reach people, answering the phone can bring problems being chased for a debt or faced with language dficulties.“We would encourage anyone called by the    number to answer and do their bit to help defeat this virus.But it is also crucial that missed calls can be followed up on the ground by public health experts experienced in contact tracing. The LGA said local authorities were best placed to deal with outbreaks because of their understanding of an area. They said: “Covid- is best understood as a pattern of local outbreaks, rather than a national pandemic with a similar impact in every community, which is why councils as local leaders have a fundamental role to play in the test and trace service.“Councils’ public health teams need to be able to use their unique expertise, including speaking other languages, and understanding of their communities to try to reach those who cannot be contacted by the test and trace system.In Blackburn with Darwen, the local council has launched its own test and trace program to contact potentially infectious residents using local knowledge after failures in the national system. Health officials in Greater Manchester are also looking into setting up their own team of virus tracers to combat the rising tide of cases in the north.Earlier this week, a major study found the UK was facing a second wave of coronavirus by December and the test  trace system was only finding  per cent of contacts of cases. The number falls far below the target of  per cent that Government scientists said needs to be hit. The boss of outsourcing giant Serco has defended the number of people being contacted and asked to isolate as part of the Test and Trace system, saying it is improving all the time.Rupert Soames, CEO of Serco, one of the providers running the test  trace call centres, defended the system claiming it had been blown out of proportion. He told BBC Radio : I think we need to get this into proportion. Youre giving me the numbers saying that were tracing % of contacts, let me tell you that % of the people that we talk to agree to self-isolate.So weve got a very, very high success rate of people that we get to contact.He blamed people being unable to recall who they had met on the failure to reach contacts of cases. He said: If somebody rang you now and I said tell me everybody that you have met, been in contact with, in the last  hours and tell me on the telephone, give me their contact details, how many do you think that youd be able to reel off of the top of your head And the fact is that about % of the contacts that people give us, say I know I sat next so somebody on a bus on the way in but I dont have their contact details. Im sorry, but my brother-in-law brought around a friend last night, I dont have their contact details. So there is an element of that and it is about % at the moment where people cant remember or never knew the contact... the details of where they were.The failed contact tracing app trialled by the Government on the Isle of Wight will be re-launched to help tell people about their infection levels in their area. A version of the app is being developed to help people use their personal information to calculate a risk score, according to The Times. The app was initially hoped to help the contact tracing effort but it failed to be accurate enough to use, and instead the Government backed Google  Apples efforts to develop a contact tracing app. Shadow health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said local authorities needed to be put in the driving seat for the system to be effective. He told BBC Radio : “The problem with the national system, where you effectively get a call from a  number from a call centre run by an outsource company like Serco, is that they are not as effective as the on the ground authority.  “When you look at the statistics, the [local authority] has a much better success rate. That’s because after  hoursSerco can’t get hold of people - which is around  per cent - they pass the contacts over to local public health officials, and they have a success rate of around  per cent. So they are clearly better at getting hold of people.”  To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The city is now teetering on the brink - with the strict measures potentially slapped on the area within days.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe ramped-up lockdown rules would see Preston follow in the footsteps of nearby East Lancashire, Greater Manchester and parts of West Yorkshire.Covid- infections have more than doubled in the city in the week to July  from  to  - almost  cases per , population.And the worrying number is the second-biggest increase behind Blackburn with Darwen, which recorded  new cases.Alarmingly, a staggering  cases were recorded in one day alone.Lancashires director of public health, Dr Sakthi Karunanithi has now warned new lockdown rules could be imposed in a bid to slow the spread.And he fears the measures could come in the next few days following a government review meeting tomorrow.He told BBC Radio Lancashire: That is my personal and professional opinion given the statistics, the direction of travel and given the size of the issue.It comes amid fury after a nightclub became the first to re-open in Britain during the crisis - despite the city teetering on the edge of lockdown.Switch threw open its doors to allow hundreds of revellers to let loose for £-a-head.Footage showed boozers stood shoulder to shoulder on the busy dancefloor.Deputy Chief Constable Terry Woods, of Lancashire Police, was among those who slammed the decision.He said to open a venue of  young people with drink is just not helpful at all.And he branded the move irresponsible as Preston was on the cusp of restrictions this week.Locals also blasted the re-opening, which came after Preston City Council made a last-minute U-turn on Saturday.This was despite the government ruling nightclubs must remain shut despite coronavirus lockdown measures easing.In a statement Switch’s owners said they had always planned to get the club back open but as a bar - rather than a nightclub.They explained: “It is, and has always been, our intention to reopen and repurpose Switch to deliver a safe and enjoyable experience... evenits as a bar.”Preston is close to Greater Manchester, East Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire, which have already been hit with lockdown rules.A major incident was even declared in Greater Manchester after coronavirus infection rates rocketed.Mayor Andy Burnham called for ato shielding, while senior figures scrambled an emergency ‘gold command’ meeting to ramp up the region’s response to the outbreak.Infection rates for the week to last Thursday - when the new measures were introduced - show cases per , people still rising in every part of the lockdowne zone.Those in Manchester and Tameside have more than doubled in seven days, while Oldhams remain the highest and the fastest-growing.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: They have also been told some doctors are dismissing many of the long-term symptoms suffered in the wake of the coronavirus as ME.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesExperts have indicated psychosis, fatigue, loss of eyesight and mobility issues are among the wide-ranging conditions that have been identied in those who have previously contracted the virus.The founder of the Long Covid Support Group Claire Hastie warned that GPs were regularly misdiagnosing ongoing problems as anxiety or ME, saying: Many people in our group to this day are being told by their GPs that its caused by anxiety and its all in their heads.It can cause anxiety, but it is not caused by anxiety. The science needs to catch up with us.She said figures from the King’s College London symptom tracker app showed that between , and , people in the UK are currently living with the long-term effects of Covid-.Giving evidence at Wednesday’s session of the All-Party Parliamentary Groupon coronavirus she said the virus had left her largely confined to a wheelchair and unable to walk  metres.Another member of the Facebook support group said his experience and left him unable to walk up a flight of stairs without losing his breath and causing him chest pain, The Dailyreports.Dr Jake Suett, an anaesthetist and intensive care doctor, said: I was doing -hour shts in ICU. Its a high-pressure situation, you have to be able to be active. I was going to the gym three times a week regularly.And now a flight of stairs or the food shop is about what I can manage before I have to stop. If Im on my feet then shortness of breath comes back, chest pain comes back.The APPG, which includes more than  MPs and peers, heard that eight in  people who had “long Covid” felt unable toto work in a normal capacity.An online survey of , people experiencing long-term symptoms found many employees felt pressured toto work despite feeling they couldn’t do so.Ms Hastie, who contracted coronavirus in March, said: Weve got people in our group whove been told or think theyll never work again. If theyve got a physical job, someones a Pilates instructor for example, she doesnt knowand when shell ever be able to work again in her chosen field of work.“People are being pressured back by employers who, understandably, dont understand this.She also said it was “not uncommon” for kids to have “long Covid”, saying that research was looking at whether genetics was a “potential factor”.Labour MP Andrew Gwynne, a member of the APPG, revealed that he had been unable to shake his own coronavirus symptoms for  weeks.I feel like [Im running] the London Marathon whenever Ive done just a basic task around the house, he said. I sometimes struggle just to ask a single Parliamentary question by Zoom, and then Ill spend the rest of the day in bed.The Royal College of General Practitioners says it expects GPs to see an influx of patients with lingering illnesses.Researchers in Italy have reported that nearly nine in  patients discharged from a Rome hospital after recovering from Covid- were still experiencing at least one symptom  days after onset.Doctors in Lombardy, the worst-affected region in Italy, warned this week that some victims may never recover from the illness.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsCoronavirus: More councils develop own track  trace as government system not fit for purposeThree councils in West Yorkshire are planning their own track and trace systems, with Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham branding the Governments one not fit for purposeShareByLucy ThorntonOliver Milne:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsManchesters Mayor Andy Burnham said the Governments track and trace system is not fit for purpose " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMore areas hit hard by Covid- are developing their own track and trace systems amid growing claims the Government’s one is flawed. Three councils in West Yorkshire plan to introduce their own way of tracking down infected residents and their contacts. Traders say it may be the only chance of saving their business. The Government’s system is “not fit for purpose”, according to Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham. The councils in Calderdale, Kirklees and Bradford are now planning to implement their own track and trace systems. Calderdale council leader Cllr Tim Swt, whose region has the sixth highest infection rate in England, said they hope theirs will be “up and running very soon”. Bradford council said bosses are in talks with the Government, while Kirklees council is in “the very early stages”.  It follows concerns about the speed and effectiveness of the £billion national system after a report this week revealed only half of contacts are being traced. Kirsty Ferridge, , who owns The Albion pub in Bradford, said she would have to shut down the boozer for goodshe is forced to close again due to another full lockdown. The Government announced last week the city was among the places to have to go into partial lockdown. Greater Manchester, Blackburn with Darwen, Burnley, Hyndburn, Pendle, Rossendale, Calderdale and Kirklees were the others.  Local authorities in eight of the worst-hit areas in England have now launched or are planning to launch their own track and trace schemes. Blackburn and Darwen council’s public health boss said the national one was “simply not tracing enough cases and contacts fast enough”. The local systems will include tracers knocking on doors as well as phoning people. Special envoy to the World Health Organisation, Dr David Nabarro, said it was “absolutely” the right move to have more locally run track and trace systems.

title: house prices lowered 30 first
story: NewsHouse prices lowered % for first-time buyers and key workers as laws ripped-upPlanning laws are being ripped up by the Tory Government to cut red tape but not standards but campaigners fear the plans will harm the environment and remove a requirement for big developers to contribute to infrastructure, piling pressure on cash strapped councilsShareByDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver Milne:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsHousing Secretary Robert Jenrick wants to make it easier to building on brownfield land " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTory ministers will on Thursday reveal plans to rip up planning regulations and lower house prices for first-time buyers and key workers by up to % in a bid to boost Britain’s housing market. Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick has claimed that this major overhaul of the planning system will speed up the housebuilding process and “cut red tape but not standards”. But campaigners are concerned that the plans will harm the environment and see Tories ditch or water-down a requirement for big developers to contribute to infrastructure around big new developments, potentially piling pressure on cash strapped councils. Mr Jenrick said the Conservatives’ latest reforms will protect green spaces while making it easier to build on “brownfield land”. The White Paper proposes a planning system with three categories of land – earmarked for growth, renewal and protection – but campaigners tonight said its risks creating a “disconnected landscape, one in which wildle continues to decline because nature doesn’t slot into neat little boxes”. Plans for the first time buyers discount, first revealed as part of the budget, are expected to feature in the White Paper. The government claims this will save buyers tens of thousands of pounds when getting on the property ladder. New aposFirst Homesapos earmarked for a discount will stay at a low price for all future owners also from the same area too. Key workers, such as nurses, police officers, firefighters, and teachers, as well as armed forces veterans, will be given priority in this scheme. However, a pilot will involve only , First Homes. And once the scheme is up and running, only % of affordable homes on a development - rather than % of all homes - will need to be First Homes. Once the % discount is applied, there will be a price cap on First Homes of £, across England and £, in London. Those buying First Homes will be subject to a household income cap of £,, or £, in London. They will mainly only be available to first-time buyers, but there will also be a list of circumstances under which non-first-time buyers should be eligible. That list is yet to be confirmed. First Homes will have to be marketed to people with local connections for the first three months after going on the market - but after that, the local restrictions will end and other people can buy them. But once the original buyer sells up, they wonapost be able to make a fat profit, the government claims. There will be a restrictive covenant against the title of the property to ensure that relevant restrictions, including the original level of discount, are passed on to future purchasers. A consultation on the plans is ongoing. Mr Jenrick said it takes seven years to agree local housing plans and five years just to get a spade in the ground, and the proposed changes aim to speed up the process. He added: “These once-in-a-generation reforms will lay the foundations for a brighter future, providing more homes for young people and creating better quality neighbourhoods and homes across the country. “We will cut red tape, but not standards, placing a higher regard on quality, design and the environment than ever before. Planning decisions will be simple and transparent, with local democracy at the heart of the process. “As we face the economic effects of the pandemic, now is the time for decisive action and a clear plan for jobs and growth. Our reforms will create thousands of jobs, lessen the dominance of big builders in the system, providing a major boost for small building companies across the country.” Matthew Fell, CBI chief UK policy director, said the reforms “will allow housebuilders to get to work”. But environmental campaigners expressed concerns. Tom Fyans, deputy chief executive of CPRE , said: “The key acid test for the planning reforms is community involvement, and on first reading it’s still not clear how this will work under a zoning system.

title: royal family having great pandemic
story: NewsopinionThe Royal Family is having a great pandemic. By contrast, the Sourpuss Sussexes are sucking on lemonsMeghan and Harry are displaying all the grace and timing of Ann Widdecombe on Strictly Come Dancing, says Fleet Street Fox. And for once the Royals havent put a foot wrongShareByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  AUG Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt was clear to everyone back in March that lockdown was about the background.Shelves. Ornaments. Ephemera that gave colleagues, friends, family, or viewers suddenly spending % of the day in front of the television, an idea of your personality as you broadcast from the back bedroom.We established, or rearranged, our home offices, and removed things that were rude or incriminating from shot. The Royal Family had their staff set up the Zoom calls, and organise hundreds of photographs in strict order of precedence and favouritism. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, on the other hand, went with a bare wall.  To be fair, it is an million wall, in a mansion theyaposve been loaned, and it is probably the only background which didnapost have some gold in it. But their minimalist approach to public le is not only in stark contrast to the Royalsapos rather cluttered one - that wall weaposve seen so much of says everything about why Meghan and Harry have had such a bad pandemic. Their escape from protocol has not given them freedom - it provided an extra barrier, behind which they have little idea of the current mood. When coronavirus meant people were denied contact with each other, they yearned to connect remotely, and for background info to fill in the blanks. All the Sussexes gave them was another blank.William and Kate gave us only a cream wall and half-open door, but it at least raised possibilities of a small Royal child bombing in to demand some foie gras. And they did oversee some elderly gambling while using bingo lingo, which is up there on the list of top Royal moments that includes parachuting into the Olympics.Harry and Meghan do a good line in earnestness. Theyaposve spoken out on issues, like Black Lives Matter and repeated Joe Bidenaposs campaign slogans, which would have been deemed too politicalthey were still aposinapos the monarchy. But, as court filings have proven, they havenapost made the best decisions. They moved to the USA  hours after Donald Trump declared a national emergency, and now find themselves at the deadly epicentre of a pandemic. Theyaposve become mired in expensive court cases on two continents, and even in their protected private enclave are so plagued by drone-operating paparazzi that they havenapost just been locked down and sealed off, theyaposve barely been into the garden.Twenty two acres, a massive swimming pool, and they canapost step off the terrace to enjoy any of it. They say their young son, whose welfare is of the utmost concern to them, hasnapost left the building once.  And while theyaposve struggled to set up a new foundation and been embarrassed by revelations the last, pointless, one cost Princess Dianaaposs charity £, to set up, the monarchy they left behind has not put a foot wrong. The Queen has Zoomed. Anne marked her th with a documentary about her le that did not involve a single complaint. Charles recovered from Covid-, and avoided criticism for importing it to Scotland. Camilla has spoken out, forcefully, about domestic abuse. And Wills and Kate have had an absolute banger - bingo, baby banks, and a curry with Peter Crouch. The things they do and say are amplied by their status. And by wearing masks in public, Camilla and Kate have done more to protect and promote public health messaging than the entire Cabinet.Harry and Meghan delivered food parcels early on, but even George and Charlotte did that. The Sussexes have since concentrated on sucking lemons and delivering speeches, which has not had the same impact since they gave up the status which gave them a loudspeaker. Prince Andrew, of course, hasnapost gone away, and nor have the allegations about his friendship with a billionaire paedophile. But they have become repetitive, and with alleged pimp Ghislaine Maxwell under lock and key some of the heat is off him, for now.The monarchyaposs popularity, and its usefulness, are in robust health. Andrew is its only weakness, and heaposs been hidden away on the Royal estates which Harry and Meghan felt didnapost hide them enough.The Sussex machine, meanwhile, is graunching its gears. Itaposs shown all the grace and timing of Ann Widdecombe spinning on her bum across the Strictly dance floor. As millions struggle to survive, physically and financially, these two gave the thumbs-up to a book that cemented their petulance in the public mind. A long list of complaints about this girl and her baggage, the sacrices they made which few of us can see, the sensible advice they ignored, and the bruised egos of a couple who thought they would inherit Dianaaposs sainthood, without having to earn it or die for it. Despite being favourable to them, it even indicates they may have lied to the world about their engagement. And the Queen comes out of it looking like she has better manners than either of them. Letaposs be frank - without Royalty, the Royals are nothing. Just an expanding group of well-fed, over-privileged, people who would not be able to earn, represent good causes or holiday for free as they do now. What Harry and Meghan are learning, the hard way, is that applies to them, too. Their star power as Royals was immense - but outside the monarchy, it is waning. They have less protection, higher costs, and the same, stratospheric expectations of the good they can do and the le they will lead.And with the book, theyaposve just burned the one-year probation period negotiated before their departure. How can they ever appear on the balcony again, with the world knowing the details of a common family ruckus, in a family thataposs not supposed to be common  The Royals hate the goldfish bowl too, but they trade the state benefits for doing things useful to the state. They hobnob with whatever nobs the Prime Minister tells them to, co-ordinate their Press appearances, share out the charity work. Their continued existence as Royals, however right or wrong it may be, is strangely socialist, and protected by that of all the others. The Sussexes left the goldfish bowl, and found themselves in a shark tank. Their only friends will be friendless celebrities, the staff less loyal, the public more sceptical, and thereaposll not be a single person able, or authorised, to protect them from what will necessarily be a nakedly capitalist descent towards, inevitably, a line of vegan lingerie.And itaposs all a damned shame, because the day that Meghan walked herself down the aisle to marry a prince with little purpose, it seemed like they would do wonders for us and each other.Instead, they were unhappy, they left everyone  unhappy, and they seem to still be unhappy. Their future holds infinite further amounts of unhappiness, with court cases that, eventhey win, will air more dirty laundry than any sane person would want, and a le that will be lived undercover.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA UK school has become the first to make coronavirus face masks compulsory for all pupils and staff, with parents forking out for specic, school unorm coverings made by a local company. Holmes Chapel Comprehensive School in leafy Cheshire is making the navy blue, embroidered masks, part of the official unorm and admits it is contrary to Government guidelines.The academy, a secondary school and sixth form centre, says masks will form part of our unorm, CheshireLive reports.In a letter to parents, the school body stated: Everyone, students and staff, MUST wear a face covering whilst inside the school buildings. This includes classrooms and corridors. Masks will form part of our unorm. We have taken this decision as a precautionary additional measure to our expected safe behaviours. On the balance of probability, the wearing of face masks is likely to make our school safer thanwe don’t wear them. The school is understood to be requiring pupils to wear navy blue, reusable face masks.Parents are instructed to purchase these from local company Sam Dale and Son, for £.  These will have HCCS embroidered on them, according to a Facebook post from the company.The school is also reminding students of the need to wash their hands. Seventy five specially sourced dispensers have been fitted outside of classrooms, continues the newsletter. Every student and member of staff must clean their hands as they enter each lesson. There are no exceptions or excuses. At the time of writing, the Government says that face masks will not be necessary in schools in England. Wearing a face covering or face mask in schools or other education settings is not recommended,states the guidance. Holmes Chapel Comprehensive School headteacher Nigel Bielby admits the school is going against the guidelines.  He told the BBC: I think we’re going contrary to the guidelines because we want to keep a community that’s safe and protect those vulnerable members of our community as far as we possibly can. We felt it was an important step that, on the balance of probability, we were more likely to feel our children and our community was safer using a face covering as opposed to not using a face covering – and of course when the children are not in those lessons and they’re outside they can take that face covering off, so the misunderstanding that the children are in a face covering for six hours a day is incorrect. “I think most of our community and our children will understand why we’ve taken this temporary measure and I think most of them will understand this is about the safety of the community and the care of our children. Councillor Kathryn Flavell, Cheshire East Council cabinet member for children and families, said: “The academy, Holmes Chapel Comprehensive, is the only school that we are aware of that has implemented a temporary arrangement of mandatory face masks for pupils when theyto school in September. “Our education team has been supporting all schools, including Holmes Chapel, to implement the guidance issued by the Department for Education on full opening from September, which clearly states that children are not expected to wear face coverings at school. “The Department for Education position is based on the best scientic advice and Public Health England does not currently recommend face coverings use as pupils and staff are mixing in consistent groups, and because misuse may inadvertently increase the risk of transmission. There may also be negative effects on communication and children’s education.

title: how primary headteacher faced down
story: NewsHow primary headteacher faced down anti-LGBT protesters outside school gatesAnderton Park Primary in Birmingham was targeted by protesters, angry at the message of equality and tolerance that was being taught to pupilsShareByJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsSarahs school was targeted by anti-LGBT protesters " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor more than two months headteacher Sarah Hewitt-Clarkson and the pupils at her primary school were subjected to constant protests outside the playground gates. Anderton Park Primary in Birmingham was one of the schools targeted by anti-gay protesters because of its stance on equality. While children were not formally taught about the importance of challenging stereotypes and treating everyone equally, the ethos of the school meant it was included in all of their values - something Sarah is passionate about. She explained: We weave teaching equality into every day conversations and we talk about how boys and girls are equal throughout the whole school. The adults in school are all good role models and we make sure we watch our language and we challenge stereotypes in school every day. But in February last year, teachers, pupils are parents when a group of protesters set up camp outside the school and home time every day. Most days it could by up to  people and on one harrowing occasion, a group of  protesters turned up and forced Sarah to close the school early. She said: The protests were aggressive and inappropriate outside a school gate. They started at around :pm every day and lasted for  minutes. They were screaming down megaphones, which is completely the opposite of the ethos of the school. We donapost shout, weaposre very harmonious and we have a good relationship with the community and our parents. Sarah spent time talking with parents who had concerns both about the protests and what they believed was being taught at school. She said: We never stopped having these discussions, itaposs really important to have these conversations so we understand them and they understand us. These might be dferent to their beliefs at home and thataposs all part of a healthy society - along with respecting each others views. But itaposs also a pivotal part of education to prepare children for le in modern Britain. Anderton Park staff were forced to take drastic action to ensure as little disruption as possible. They changed the exits the pupils used at the end of every school day to keep them away from the protests - but it still had an impact on the children. Sarah said: The noise was awful. The protests were closest to our youngest children so it was terrible for them, as well as for the staff. But children are very resilient and couldnapost understand what was happening. They all understand equality completely. Sarah, who describes herself as a fiercely proud Brummie, and her team worked closely with Birmingham City Council to try to bring an end to the protests and ended up taking the protesters to court. But despite the ordeal she was putting up with daily, Sarah was never once tempted to back down. She said: Iaposm pretty resilient andanyone is going to take me, then doing it over equality is a good idea because itaposs very important to me. There was no way we were backing down.  If you bow down to one belief, itaposs a slippery slope. If you say itaposs not OK to say that some children have two dads, then you have to bow down to every belief. But it was pretty awful. I felt at one point that my soul had been crushed and I wasnapost sure I was ever going to get it back. I had a lot of good people around me, the brilliant kids at school, the senior leadership team, the staff at school, my two daughters and my partner. Finally, a court granted an injunction which meant the protesters had to be a certain distance from the school. While the children could still hear them, it wasnapost as threatening as it had been. Finally, last November, the courts granted an injunction that officially moved the protesters on.  Now the protesters are finally gone - although a few arrived when school started back again in September - Sarah has had a new crisis to deal with. The coronavirus pandemic. While Anderton Park has been empty of pupils for several months its headteacher has been a regular within its walls. Sarah cleared the schoolaposs freezers and food cupboards to provide food parcels for struggling families. A third of the pupils at the school are entitled to free school meals and with large families and small budgets common, many didnapost have access to the tehcnology to enable them to learn from home.

Bars, cafes and restaurants have been ordered to close by pm on Wednesday by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon following an outbreak of  cases in the city. The -year-old monarch and the Duke of Edinburgh, who is , arrived at Aberdeen International Airport on Tuesday for their annual summer break at the royal pile in Royal Deeside, Aberdeenshire. The lockdown had been rolled out again as a surge in cases has heightens fears the Scottish Government is dealing with a signicant outbreak in Aberdeen that may include some community transmission, Ms Sturgeon said. A five-mile travel rule has been put in place and residents are being told not to enter each otheraposs houses and indoor and outdoor hospitality venues must close.  The measures, which apply to the Aberdeen City area, will be backed by government regulations, the First Minister said, and will be enforcedthe rules are not followed. The Scottish Government later announced that visits to hospital and care homes from a named family member or friend will be stopped, with only essential visits being allowed. The decision was taken following a meeting of the Scottish Government Resilience Committee , which also included leaders of Aberdeen City Council, NHS Grampian and Police Scotland. Ms Sturgeon added the decision to reimpose some measures was taken to prevent further spread and to give the Test and Protect teams the best possible chance of successfully breaking these chains of transmission. The First Minister said people should not travel to Aberdeen, but those who are already there can remain. She added the changes will be reviewed next Wednesday, when she hopes they could be removed, either in entirety or in part. Ms Sturgeon said they could be extended beyond that seven-day periodnecessary.Speaking at the coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh on Wednesday, she said the rise in cases has contributed to a greater fear there has been a signicant outbreak in the city. NHS Grampian has named  bars and restaurants, three golf clubs and a football club as venues visited by people linked to the cluster. story: NewsToy Storys original Buzz is unrecognisable and even had entirely dferent nameThese never-seen-before sketches of Buzz have been released to mark the th anniversary of the first film – and show how dferent the classic Pixar movie could have lookedShareByKeir Mudie:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsBuzz could have looked very dferent and had a totally dferent name " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe success of the Toy Story films has taken Buzz and Woody’s fame to infinity and beyond. But as these never-seen-before sketches of Buzz reveal – released to mark the th anniversary of the first film – it could all have been so dferent. Instead of the space ranger we have all come to know and love, animators at Pixar experimented with a series of dferent faces, colours and designs. Pixar historian Christine Freeman said: “Buzz is one of our most popular characters and it’s fascinating to see the dferent ways that Pixar’s artists imagined him during the evolution of his design. “Even his name changed over time – from Tempus of Morph to Lunar Larry, to Buzz Lightyear. You can see the LL belt buckle for Lunar Larry in a few of these early designs.” Since the first ever full- computer animated feature hit cinemas in November, , the Toy Story franchise has made an incredible £.billion worldwide. But it very nearly fell at the first hurdle. Back in , then fledgling animation firm Pixar signed a £m deal with Disney to produce three fully animated feature films.The problem was they’d never made one before. “We didn’t have any production expertise except for short films and commercials. So we were all complete novices,” says retired Pixar president Ed Catmull. Straight away there were problems with production, technology and scripts. And Disney, who could kill the deal – and Pixar – at any moment were getting impatient. In November,  – a date Pixar insiders refer to as “Black Friday” – they showed a rough cut of the film. The reaction was not good. “Guys, no matter how much you try to fix it,” Disney animation chief Peter Schneider said, “It just isn’t working.”  Although the animation was impressive, the story was flat and the characters were unrecognisable – sarcastic and cruel with a strained relationship between Buzz and Woody. Tom Hanks, who voiced Woody, said: “At first they were saying, ‘we want you to improvise, we want you to get at each other, you could be sarcastic with one another’. “It turned into a sort of cynicism that wasn’t really part of what the original sense of the DNA was.” Disney shut down production and the Pixar animators and writers locked themselves away to try to save their movie – and their company. They thrashed out a new storyline – with the bickering but warm friendship between Buzz and Woody at its heart. Screenwriter Andrew Stanton said: “It’s the ugliest picture we will ever make, but you don’t care because you get wrapped up in the story to this day.” Disney were shown the new version of the film and liked what they saw.  In March, , the actors including Hanks, Tim Allen, and Annie Potts, ed to Pixar to record the new script. The relaxed atmosphere gave the actors more freedom and many of the most famous scenes from the first movie are ad libs by Hanks who was just allowed to go off script and mess around with props left in the recording studio. And changes to the script were happening every day as Pixar literally made things up as they went along. This was where Buzz went through his ious incarnations – until they settled on the name and look we know so well. Director John Lasseter, who has since left Pixar after accusations of sexual misconduct, said: “My favourite colour is bright green and my we’s is purple. Just like she and I, they go really well together.” Woody was originally supposed to be a ventriloquist dummy, but producers said it was “creeping people out” and made the change to a lovable cowboy with his trademark pull-string.

CCTV footage shows the heroic woman slowly vacuum cleaning as the little girl wanders across the play area just before one of the biggest non-nuclear explosions of all time. And within a matter of seconds, window blinds rock forwards before the glass windows burst into smithereens from the shockwave of the blast. But with an incredible piece of quick-thinking, the maid quickly leans over and grabs the girl and pulls her close to her chest. She abandons the cleaning and flees the room. More than  people - at least  - were killed in the huge blast which wrought devastation in the capital of Lebanon. The cataclysmic explosion, caused by , tons of ammonium nitrate, left , people injured and the city resembling a scrapyard of destroyed buildings. The explosion was a fth of the she size of the Hiroshima nuclear bomb and is thought to have been triggered by a fire was sparked by a welder. Shocking videos showed a huge mushroom cloud over the city. Lebanese rescue workers searched for survivors in the mangled wreckage of buildings and investigators today blamed negligence for the disaster.  Up to , were left without homes fit to live in after shockwaves smashed building facades, sucked furniture out into streets and shattered windows miles inland. The death toll was expected to rise. The damage is thought to have spiralled to more than billion, with thousands left homeless. Lebanese President Michel Aoun said , tonnes of ammonium nitrate had been stored for six years at the port without safety measures.  He declared a two-week state of emergency for Beirut and vowed the harshest punishments for those responsible. Ammonium nitrate is an industrial chemical commonly used in fertilisers and as an explosive for quarrying and mining. It is an oxidiser considered relatively safeuncontaminated and stored properly. But it is extremely dangerouscontaminated, mixed with fuel or stored unsafely. A large quantity of ammonium nitrate exposed to intense heat can trigger an explosion. Storing the chemical near large fuel tanks, in bulk in large quantities and in a poorly-ventilated facility could cause a massive blast. The larger the quantity, the more risk it will detonate.  On a scale, this explosion is scaled down from a nuclear bomb rather than up from a conventional bomb, said Roland Alford, managing director of Alford Technologies, a British company that specialises in disposal of explosive ordnance. This is probably up there among the biggest non-nuclear explosions of all time. Experts have noted the colour of the smoke and mushroom cloud seen in footage of Tuesdayaposs blast as characteristic of ammonium nitrate explosions.Video footage of the incident show initial white-grey smoke followed by an explosion that released a large cloud of red-brown smoke and a large white aposmushroom cloudapos. These indicate that the gasses released are white ammonium nitrate fumes, toxic, red brown nitrous oxide and water, said Stewart Walker from the school of Forensic, Environmental and Analytical Chemistry at Flinders University. If you make ammonium nitrate explosive, you shouldnapost get that brown plume. That tells me the oxygen balance was not correct - so it wasnapost mixed as an explosive, he said. The Beirut blast looks like an accident, unless it was arson.  Some of the worldaposs deadliest industrial accidents were caused by ammonium nitrate explosions. In , an explosion of ammonium sulphate and nitrate fertiliser at the Oppau plant in Germany killed  people. In , a fire detonated around , tonnes of the chemical aboard a vessel in the U.S. port of Texas City, causing a tidal wave. At least  people were killed and more than , injured.  In Toulouse, France in , an explosion at an ammonium nitrate depot killed  and injured ,. Ammonium nitrate stored at a Texas fertiliser plant detonated in an explosion that killed  and injured about  in . In , explosions at a warehouse storing ammonium nitrate and other chemicals in the Chinese port of Tianjin killed at least  people.  Andrea Sella, professor of Inorganic Chemistry at the University of Calornia, Los Angeles, said of the Beirut blast: The idea that such a quantity would have been left unattended for six years beggars belief, and was an accident waiting to happen. Ammonium nitrate can be mixed with other substances to make a bomb. It was used in Irish Republican Armybombings in London in the s, the  explosion that blew up a federal building in Oklahoma City, killing  people, and the  blasts in Bali nightclubs in which more than  died.

title: day bomb fell hiroshima flesh
story: NewsThe day the bomb fell on Hiroshima flesh fell from bodies and stomachs burst openEXCLUSIVE Setsuko Nakamura, was just  when an atomic bomb hit Hiroshima, in Japan, and she can still recall how bloodied semi-naked people staggered around like ghosts after the explosionShareByNick Harding:,  AUG NewsSome , people died immediately when an atomic bomb hit Hiroshima " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSeventy-five years ago, at .am on August  , there was a flash above the Japanese city of Hiroshima so intense it blinded those who looked directly at it. A white-hot blastwave pulsed across the city, obliterating any building within a five-mile radius. Some , died immediately and the mushroom cloud rained deadly radioactivity on those left. Another , died of horric injuries within days. The bomb was called Little Boy – the world’s first atomic weapon. Three days later another atomic bomb was dropped on the city of Nagasaki. Setsuko Nakamura, , was arriving for her first day as a codebreaker with the army in Hiroshima on August th. Survivors of the world’s only atomic attacks are called “hibakushas” – “person affected by a bomb” – and there are just , left. Setsuko, now  and living in Canada, joined The International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons, accepting the Nobel Peace Prize for the group in . Here, she recounts what happened the day the world changed for ever... “It was Monday morning. We were on the second floor of the wooden building. The major was giving us a pep talk. At that moment I saw the bluest white flash outside and all around the building. “My body flew in the air. I was floating. I lost consciousness. I came to in total darkness. I couldn’t move. I was pinned under collapsed timbers and knew I was facing death. I was calm. I heard girls whispering. ‘Mother, help me, I am here’, ‘God help me’. Then a strong male voice told me, ‘Don’t give up. Keep moving, I am trying to free you, there is light ahead of you, crawl towards it.’ “I did and I escaped along with two other girls. I looked back and the building was on fire. About  girls with me in the room were burned alive. Outside, it was as dark as twilight.  “As my eyes adjusted, I saw a procession of human beings, they looked like ghosts. They were almost naked, their clothes in tatters, they were burned and blackened, swollen and bleeding, skin and flesh was coming off their bones. They were slowly shuffling from the centre of the city. Some people were carrying their eyeballs in the palms of their hands. Some fell and their stomachs burst open. Soldiers told us to join them and escape to a nearby hill. We walked over the bodies. “At the foot of the hill was a training field. It was packed with dead and dying. No one was screaming or crying. Just moans and whispers. Tens of thousands were begging for water. There was not a single doctor or nurse. The people were left there.  “With the other two girls, I worked all day trying to help. When darkness fell, we climbed the hill and I watched all night as huge balls of fire incinerated my hometown. My mind was empty. I sat there without any emotion watching the horror. Some envied the dead. To live in the aftermath was as hard or harder than dying. We were starving. There was no medical attention. The government was in chaos. “The next day people started to come from neighbouring cities, they tried to rescue survivors, started cremating the corpses. Those who came to assist started to get sick too. At that time, we had no idea what radiation would do. The rescuers became victims. I started losing my hair, there was internal bleeding.  “Before the bomb, about , other students from all the schools around were brought to the city to work. They died instantly, some vaporised. There were  from my school there. All those people were wiped from the Earth. “My own sister-in-law was a teacher supervising those students. We tried to find her body. We never did. The temperature was C. People melted. I lost nine two uncles, two aunts, two cousins, my sister-in-law, my sister and her four-year-old child. They survived the blast but were badly burned.  “My mother was rescued from a crushed building. My father was out of town fishing. From the boat, he saw the mushroom cloud. He got to where our house stood. It had been flattened. My parents found me and we went to look after my sister and her child. We spent days with them until they died. “The soldiers came, dug a hole, threw the bodies in, poured gasoline in and threw in a match. There was no human dignity. I watched without any feeling. I was stunned.

title: queen speaks out beirut blast
story: NewsQueen speaks out on Beirut blast as search for survivors amongst devastation continuesIn a message to the the President of the Republic of Lebanon Michel Aoun, Her majesty said she and the Duke of Edinburgh were "deeply saddened" by the devastating newsShareBySophie MorrisGeorge Ryan:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsThe Queen said her thoughts and prayers were with all those affected " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen has spoken out following the aftermath of a huge blast in the Lebanese capital, Beirut, last night. In a message to the the President of the Republic of Lebanon, Michel Aoun, Her majesty said she and the Duke of Edinburgh were deeply saddened by the news. The Queenaposs message to Mr Aoun said: Prince Philip and I were deeply saddened by news of the explosion at the Port in Beirut yesterday. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families and friends of those who have been injured or lost their lives, and all those whose homes and livelihoods have been affected. At least  have been confirmed dead and more than , people injured.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the Government is ready to provide support in any way we can, while the Foreign Office said it is monitoring the situation closely. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said the UK stands in solidarity with Lebanon.My thoughts and prayers are with those affected by the devastating explosion in Beirut today. The UK stands in solidarity with the people of Lebanon and is ready to offer help and support, including to those British nationals impacted, he said. President Michel Aoun said the blast was caused by , tonnes of ammonium nitrate being stored unsafely in a warehouse.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: The images of explosions in Beirut are deeply worrying. Our thoughts are with those affected, the emergency services and the people of Lebanon. A spokesman for the Foreign Office said: All embassy staff are accounted for. A small number have sustained non-le-threatening injuries and, where necessary, are receiving medical attention. It is a fast-moving situation and we are monitoring the situation closely. We stand ready to offer consular support to British nationals affected. People should check FCO travel advice, which is updated regularly and includes contact details for those requiring consular assistance. Tory Defence Select Committee chairman Tobias Ellwood said the Government should offer the services of the UKaposs hospital ship, RFA Argus, to Lebanon.  In a tweet, he said: With Beirut hospitals overwhelmedthis asset should be part of our support offered to Lebanon. Abbas Ibrahim, chief of Lebanese General Security, said the blast might have been caused by highly explosive material that was confiscated from a ship some time ago and stored at the port.But US President Donald Trump said US military generals had told him they seem to feel the explosion was the result of a terrible attack most likely caused by a bomb.It would seem like it based on the explosion, Mr Trump told reporters in Washington. Mr Gibb said the US President was premature to speculate.  The Lebanese government have announced that they are conducting an inquiry and we are ready to help support the Lebanese government with any technical support that they need, but this is a tragedy and the Lebanese authorities are, of course, investigating the cause of that tragedy and I think before we have the results of that inquiry, I think it is premature to speculate, he told Sky News. Mr Gibb went on: We are, as a Government, working urgently this morning on what support we can offer to the Lebanese government, whether that is technical support or financial support. He added that the Government donapost know yet how many British nationals are affected and that the prime minister of Lebanon has asked for assistance.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A blushing bride was posing for a wedding video shoot and showing off her long white gown when a massive explosion rocked Beirut and sent her running for cover.The terrying scene was caught on camera as Dr Israa Seblaniaposs celebration with her husband Ahmad Subeih, , turned into fears that she would die. Footage shows Dr Seblani, , who works in the US, smiling and looking radiant in her dress, but as photographer Mahmoud Nakib pans the camera down to a bouquet on the floor there is a deafening roar and the whole area shakes as the force of the blast blows the train on the wedding gown. The camera then shows a street that is filled with dust and debris as buildings fall apart and windows are blown out by the powerful shockwave that nearly blows the bride off her feet. Have you been affected by the explosion  Email webnews@mirror. Tuesdayaposs blast killed  people, injured more than , and left dozens missing as rescuers searched through mounds of rubble. Still in her wedding dress, Dr Seblani helped to check on the injured nearby, before fleeing central Beirutaposs Sai square to safety. Later, as she spoke to a Reuters journalist, she and her husband, a businessman in Beirut, were struggling to process what happened. She said: I have been preparing for my big day for two weeks and I was so happy like all other girls, aposI am getting marriedapos. My parents are going to be happy seeing me in a white dress, I will be looking like a princess.What happened during the explosion here - there is no word to explain ... I was shocked, I was wondering what happened, am I going to die  How am I going to die  Behind her, piles of smashed glass from the blown-out windows of the hotel where she was due to stay littered the ground, along with crushed remnants of flower arrangements that had adorned banquet tables. Dr Seblani arrived in Beirut three weeks earlier to prepare for her wedding. Mr Subeih recalled the aftermath of the blast, which officials have blamed on a huge stockpile of highly explosive material - , tonnes of ammonium nitrate, used in fertilisers and bombs - stored for years in unsafe conditions at the port. He said: We started to walk around and it was extremely sad, it was not describable the devastation and the sound of the explosion. We are still in shock ... I have never heard anything similar to the sound of this explosion. Dr Seblani added: I feel so sad about what happened to other people, about what happened to Lebanon. When I woke up [on Wednesday morning] and saw the damage that happened to Beirut, the one thing I said was thank God we are still alive.  After the blast, she and her husband tried to compose themselves and carry on with their celebrations. She said: My husband told me to continue, we canapost stop. I was like okay, why not, we continue. I was not living the moment actually, I was like walking, my face was smiling, my lips were smiling, thataposs it, not more. Then we went to have a dinner. Mr Subeih recalls entering the damaged hotel on Wednesday to retrieve belongings and passports. He said: The scene in the room was unbelievable.He is waiting for a visa to the United States so he can join his we there. Dr Seblani loves Lebanon, but feels that after Tuesdayaposs blast, living there is not an option. She is still trying to find joy in a wedding she took so long to prepare. The bride said: There is a lot of damage, many people were killed and wounded. But alsoI want to look at us, myself, my husband, the photographer - how we escaped unharmed, I thank God for protecting us.

title: danny mullen out to prove himself at dundee after signing two year deal at dens park
story: New Dundee striker Danny Mullen is out to prove himself at Dens Park after signing a two-year deal with the club.Having won the Championship with St Mirren after leaving a Livingston side destined for the Premiership themselves, Mullen has pedigree in the second tier.And he’s looking to show that in dark blue when the season gets going in October.Speaking to Dee TV, he said: “I’m buzzing to be here. It’s been a long time coming. I can’t wait to get started and meet all the boys.“Now I’m here I want to prove to the manager and prove to the team I can help the club get where they want to be.“I know the league well, I’ve done well in the league before and I can see myself doing well at a club like this. It’s a massive club and the players here are top quality so I’m really forward to getting going.”The -year-old came very close to joining James McPake’s men back in January, only for time to run out at the end of the transfer window.And he says knowing the Dens boss has been an admirer for some time helped make the decision to sign up for the Dee six months later.He added: “It was really close, just didn’t quite work out, but I’m here now and happy to be here.“I think it’s half the battle being at a club that the manager likes you.”Mullen, who will wear the number nine jersey, will already have won over some fans after his play-off goal helped keep the Buddies in the Premiership at the end of season - at the expense of local rivals Dundee United.Meanwhile, former Dens loan ace Christophe Berra insists he is ready to revive his Hearts career after being unceremoniously axed by former boss Daniel Stendel.Berra, , remains baffled by the German’s decision to strip him of the captaincy and farm him out on loan to Dundee in January, emphasising that he was willing to fight for his place.He was excellent for James McPake’s side, who kept five clean sheets in six games featuring the veteran stopper.But Berra will go up against Dee with the Jambos in the Championship this season after reporting back for duty following the shutdown with renewed confidence.The defender, who is contracted to Hearts until next summer, is determined to battle his way into the plans of ing head coach Robbie Neilson, his ex-Tynecastle team-mate, and prove that age is no barrier.Reflecting on his enforced exile, Berra told the BBC: “I could understandI was a bad egg but I’m not.“I was happy to stay and fight for my place but the manager came in and you’ve got to respect his decision.“I went to Dundee and, looking back, that was a great thing for me. I played in six games, undefeated, kept five clean sheets and enjoyed my football.“I know I can still play at a good level. I don’t care about age #you are learning every day, putting in the sht and performing well then you can play far beyond your years.“I’ll do my utmost in training and, come the first game of the season,the manager decides to pick me, then great.“There are no guarantees in football no matter who you are. It’ll be down to me, in terms of how I perform in training and pre-season games.”Dundee and Hearts go head to head at Tynecastle on October , the Championship’s opening day, and Berra acknowledges the capital club are favourites for the title.However, he warned against anything approaching complacency.Berra added: “We have expectations as a club and, there’s not point hiding it, everyone expects us to go up.#We’re the hot favourites but in football, and sport in general, you need to earn the right to go up.“Every team we play against will be trying their hardest # and there are good teams down there good players. We need to have the right attitude and application.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: 4 5 health bosses to discuss aberdeens coronavirus recovery plan
story: Councillors in Aberdeen will discuss the vision for the next phase in the response to the Covid- pandemic.Operation Home First is a partnership between the health and social care partnerships in the Granite City, Aberdeenshire, Moray and NHS Grampian’s acute services.The project involves providing more health care to people at home and it is aimed at making sure there is a plan in place to deal with any future demand on services, as well as meeting the needs of vulnerable people.Members of Aberdeen City Council’s integrated joint board will be asked to note the progress being made on the scheme in the city when they meet on Tuesday.A report prepared by Sandra McLeod, chief officer for Aberdeen health and social care partnership updates councillors on the project.It said that since it was discussed in May steps have been taken to move forward with  so-called transformations in response to the pandemic being highlighted.These include the closure of care of the elderly beds at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, moving staff and beds to Woodend hospital and using the Near Me virtual GP appointment service.The report said: “Some of these changes have now been embedded and other activities are now ongoing to further embed these changes and continue to deliver the objectives of Operation Home First and hence our own strategic priorities.“Some of these have been done within the partnership, and others within Acute or across the wider system.”The document also said that with a “risk” of further outbreaks of Covid- could impact on health services and staff.It said that while Operation Home First is part of the recovery plan it also means health services are equipped for any further outbreaks.It said: “There is a risk that the coronavirusoutbreak leads to high numbers of incidences within the city, impacting public health and the delivery of essential health and care services through signicantly increased demand and reduced workforce capacity.This reduced capacity arising as a result of frontline workforce absence and self-isolation requirements.“Operation Home First is the beginning of our recovery from the initial phase of the Covid- pandemic, ensuring services can continue to be delivered in a safe, but transformed way, whilst also preparing to be equipped for any future re-emergence of virus within the community.”Meanwhile, members of the integrated joint board will also discuss a motion from the urgent business committee calling for increased Scottish Government funding for social care.A report into the referral from councillors is recommending the IJB note the issues highlighted by councillors.It said: “There is a risk that the IJB does not make representation to the Scottish Government to identy the issues and seek additional monies and later finds itself in financial dficulty.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web +
